newsitem.title: USA: CSCE coffee ends higher, spot premium widens.
newsitem.headline: CSCE coffee ends higher, spot premium widens.

text.p: CSCE coffee prices strode higher again on Thursday, as renewed concern about near-term supplies fueled aggressive buying of the spot contract month, trading sources said.

The stock jitters, which were revived earlier in the week when the CSCE reported deliverable inventories had fallen to their lowest level in more than a decade, drove the spot December contract to its highest settlement in four weeks.

Benchmark December futures rose a solid 2.05 cents per lb on the day, to 107.45 cents, having ranged from 105.10 to 107.70. Buying on the deferreds was more cautious, with second-position March gaining 1.50, to 102.30.
"There is a real tightness is the physical market," said Victor Henriquez, president of trading firm Hencorp Becstone.
"You don't see any coffee coming in yet from Central America...and roasters need to start buying as the weather turns colder and demand picks up."

The sharp downturn in weekly certified stocks was the main impetus behind the widening spot-month premium, he added. December-March swelled to 5.15 cents Thursday, compared with 3.45 cents at the start of the week.

But analysts said coffee would need to punch through the 108-110 cent area in the next several days to sustain the bullish trend. And as long as producer-countries remained eager sellers at the highs, the uptrend may be short-lived, they said.

"It does look like we have built a nice base," said Jim Cordier, analyst with Allendale Commodities. "(But) we're getting overbought, going sideways for the past two weeks, and December desperately needs a close over 110 cents."

In the options ring, straddles were well traded at 90-115 cents, generating additional speculative interest on the futures, traders said. November coffee options expire on Friday. Volume was estimated at 6,852 lots.
-- Wendy Pollack, New York Commodities Desk +1 212 859 1640
